description:
This allows Gadget and OWLS simulations to load a ``SimulationTimeSeries`` object with the ``simulation`` command.

One can now do:

```
#!python

import yt
sim = yt.simulation("lcdm_gas.param", "Gadget") # or "OWLS"
sim.get_time_series()
for ds in sim:
    # do stuff
```

I am in the process of getting a sample dataset to be used with this, but that may take some time.  If any Gadget or OWLS users are able to test this, I would greatly appreciate it.
title: Adding SimulationTimeSeries support for Gadget and OWLS.

pullrequest.title: Adding SimulationTimeSeries support for Gadget and OWLS.

content.raw: FWIW, even if not a grid, all of these will be defined.  `domain_dimensions` for particle datasets is currently always going to be `[2,2,2]` but will be slightly different in the future.  Octree datasets will have meaningful entries for all of these items, as well as grid.
content.html: FWIW, even if not a grid, all of these will be defined. domain_dimensions for particle datasets is currently always going to be [2,2,2] but will be slightly different in the future. Octree datasets will have meaningful entries for all of these items, as well as grid.

content.raw: This should be `line.split(None, 1)` to handle all whitespace (including \t), not just space chars.  Without this change, I fail on reading in some datasets where people were more liberal with their use of tabs.
content.html: This should be line.split(None, 1) to handle all whitespace (including \t), not just space chars. Without this change, I fail on reading in some datasets where people were more liberal with their use of tabs.

pullrequest.title: Adding SimulationTimeSeries support for Gadget and OWLS.

content.raw: Something that threw me for a loop here was that get_time_series() doesn't search the local directory for outputs, it searches the output path specified in the original simulation parameter file.  So if the original simulation was done using an absolute path, and the outputs get moved, then get_time_series quietly finds zero outputs.  Of course, by simply changing the parameter file line: `OutputDir     .`, it will not look in the present directory for these outputs, but it isn't obvious that this is what is going on.  Maybe there is something that can be done to address this?  It may be too much work to search for either the path specified in the parameter file, or if that fails, then look in the present directory, but that is the most intuitive.  Alternatively, just providing a warning message that when 0 datasets are found, perhaps the user should check the OutputDir path in the parameter file?  Or at the very least, we could include a note in the docstrings for get_time_series().  I just think it may be a common problem that others run into in the future.
content.html: Something that threw me for a loop here was that get_time_series() doesn't search the local directory for outputs, it searches the output path specified in the original simulation parameter file. So if the original simulation was done using an absolute path, and the outputs get moved, then get_time_series quietly finds zero outputs. Of course, by simply changing the parameter file line: OutputDir ., it will not look in the present directory for these outputs, but it isn't obvious that this is what is going on. Maybe there is something that can be done to address this? It may be too much work to search for either the path specified in the parameter file, or if that fails, then look in the present directory, but that is the most intuitive. Alternatively, just providing a warning message that when 0 datasets are found, perhaps the user should check the OutputDir path in the parameter file? Or at the very least, we could include a note in the docstrings for get_time_series(). I just think it may be a common problem that others run into in the future.

pullrequest.title: Adding SimulationTimeSeries support for Gadget and OWLS.

content.raw: maybe leave off the find_outputs kwarg here, since it is False by default.  Also, I cannot seem to get the find_outputs kwarg to work in my scripts.  Perhaps in the future, we can just make it so that when find_outputs=True, it automatically calls get_time_series() with no arguments, since that is what most people probably want to do anyway.  Then it removes an extra line of code from most people's scripts to use this awesome feature.
content.html: maybe leave off the find_outputs kwarg here, since it is False by default. Also, I cannot seem to get the find_outputs kwarg to work in my scripts. Perhaps in the future, we can just make it so that when find_outputs=True, it automatically calls get_time_series() with no arguments, since that is what most people probably want to do anyway. Then it removes an extra line of code from most people's scripts to use this awesome feature.

pullrequest.title: Adding SimulationTimeSeries support for Gadget and OWLS.

content.raw: We should figure out why it's not working with ``find_outputs=True``.  It was working for me, so it's possible there are some minor differences in the frontend.  I actually use ``find_outputs=True`` with additional kwargs to ``get_time_series`` all the time.  If the time interval between datasets changes during the simulation, it's the only the way to work with that properly.
content.html: We should figure out why it's not working with find_outputs=True. It was working for me, so it's possible there are some minor differences in the frontend. I actually use find_outputs=True with additional kwargs to get_time_series all the time. If the time interval between datasets changes during the simulation, it's the only the way to work with that properly.
